topics.topic_name: Food: Where Does It Come From

in_scope: Plants and animals as sources of food
Different plant parts used as food: roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds
Animal products: milk, eggs, meat, honey
Herbivores: animals that eat only plants
Carnivores: animals that eat only other animals
Omnivores: animals that eat both plants and animals
Food ingredients and their sources
Examples of food items and their plant/animal origins
out_of_scope: Detailed nutrition and nutrients — Covered in Components of Food topic
Food chains and food webs — Introduced in Class 7
Digestion process — Introduced in Class 7
Photosynthesis details — Introduced in Class 7

in_scope: Carbohydrates: energy-giving foods (rice, wheat, sugar, potatoes)
Proteins: body-building foods (pulses, milk, eggs, fish, meat)
Fats: energy-giving foods (oils, butter, ghee, nuts)
Vitamins A, B, C, D and their sources
Important minerals: iron, calcium, iodine
Roughage (dietary fibre) and water as essential components
Balanced diet: meals with all nutrients in right amounts
Deficiency diseases: scurvy, rickets, beri-beri, goitre, anaemia, night blindness
Simple tests for starch, protein, and fat in food
out_of_scope: Chemical structure of nutrients — Introduced in Class 7
Detailed digestion and absorption — Introduced in Class 7
Calorie counting and detailed dietary planning — Introduced in Class 8
Enzyme functions — Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Types of plants: herbs, shrubs, and trees
Parts of a plant and their functions
Types of roots and leaf venation

in_scope: Herbs: small plants with soft/green stems (wheat, mint, coriander)
Shrubs: medium-sized plants with hard stems branching near the base (rose, jasmine)
Trees: tall plants with hard, thick stems (mango, neem, peepal)
Climbers and creepers as additional categories
Root: anchoring and absorption of water and minerals
Stem: transport of water and nutrients
Leaf: photosynthesis and transpiration
Flower: reproduction
Tap root and fibrous root systems
Reticulate and parallel venation in leaves
Parts of a flower: sepals, petals, stamens, pistil
Basic concept of pollination
out_of_scope: Photosynthesis mechanism — Introduced in Class 7
Plant cell structure — Introduced in Class 8
Fertilisation and seed formation details — Introduced in Class 7
Plant tissues — Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Human skeletal system and types of joints
Movement in animals: gaits and adaptations

in_scope: Human body has 206 bones forming the skeleton
Functions of skeleton: shape, support, protection, movement
Ball and socket joint: allows movement in all directions (shoulder, hip)
Pivot joint: allows rotation (neck)
Hinge joint: allows movement in one direction (knee, elbow)
Fixed joint: no movement (skull bones)
Rib cage protects heart and lungs
Backbone (vertebral column) and its structure
Cartilage: softer than bone (ear, nose tip)
Muscles contract and relax to cause movement
Movement in earthworm, snail, cockroach, fish, bird, snake
out_of_scope: Detailed muscular system — Introduced in Class 7
Bone marrow and blood cell production — Introduced in Class 8
Detailed anatomy of vertebral column — Introduced in Class 8
Muscle tissue types — Introduced in Class 9

topics.topic_name: The Living Organisms and Their Surroundings

concepts.concept_name: Types of habitats: terrestrial and aquatic
Biotic and abiotic components of habitat

in_scope: Habitat: place where organisms live
Adaptation: special features that help organisms survive in their habitat
Terrestrial habitats: deserts, forests, grasslands, mountains
Aquatic habitats: freshwater (ponds, rivers) and marine (oceans)
Desert adaptations: camel (hump, long legs), cactus (thick stem, spines)
Aquatic adaptations: fish (gills, streamlined body, fins), frog (webbed feet)
Mountain adaptations: yak (thick fur), snow leopard
Characteristics of living organisms: respiration, excretion, response to stimuli, reproduction, growth, movement, nutrition
Biotic components: plants, animals, microorganisms
Abiotic components: air, water, soil, sunlight, temperature
out_of_scope: Ecosystem and ecological balance — Introduced in Class 7
Food chains and food webs — Introduced in Class 7
Evolution and natural selection — Introduced in Class 10
Biome classification — Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Types of waste: biodegradable and non-biodegradable

in_scope: Biodegradable waste: materials that decompose naturally (food scraps, paper, cotton)
Non-biodegradable waste: materials that do not decompose easily (plastic, glass, metal)
Landfills: disposal sites for waste
Composting: conversion of organic waste into manure
Vermicomposting: using earthworms to make compost (redworms)
The 3Rs: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), Recycle (make new products)
Harmful effects of burning garbage: air pollution
Segregation of waste into dry and wet
Paper recycling as an example of recycling
Plastic as a major environmental concern
out_of_scope: Detailed microbiology of decomposition — Introduced in Class 8
Sewage treatment — Introduced in Class 7
Industrial waste management — Introduced in Class 8
Ozone depletion and global warming — Introduced in Class 8
